Okey, Clara A.
            Died: ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Died: >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 May 12, 1913
 
 
======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711
Okey, Cornelius
The Spirit of Democracy issued dated 4 October 1859, Vol. XVI, No. 30 published Woodsfield, OH
     Col. ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Col. >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Cornelius Okey, one of the earliest settlers in this country, died at his residence one half mile north east of this place, on Friday morning, Sept. 23, 1859. He was the eldest son of Judge Levin Okey, and was born in Lewistown, Sussex County, Delaware, on the 3rd of January 1783. In the spring of 1800, he <<<<<<< HEAD removed with his fathers family to the mouth of Captina, in Belmont County, in ======= removed with his father s family to the mouth of Captina, in Belmont County, in >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 this State, where, on the 5th of February, 1805, he was married to Hannah Wier, whom he survived seven years. The issue of the marriage was thirteen children, seven sons and six daughters, all of whom are still living.
     In the ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> In the >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Spring of 1815, he removed to the farm on which he resided at the time of his decease. We do not use the word farm as now understood, for then it was an unbroken forest. Here he settled down, cleared out his farm, reared his family, and grew up with the country. At that day the facilities for acquiring an education were extremely limited, but being possessed of a strong native intellect, he to a very considerable extent overcame the disadvantage of the lack of early education; and shortly after the organization of the County, we find him filling important political stations. In 1825, he represented the County in the State legislature, and afterWards was re-elected to the same office several times.--He also filled the office of Auditor and Recorder and that of Sheriff <<<<<<< HEAD from 1835 to 1839, and was a Justice of the Peace for many years.All these ======= from 1835 to 1839, and was a Justice of the Peace for many years. All these >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 stations he filled with satisfaction to his constituents, and credit to himself.
The virtues of bravery and hospitality he possessed in common with nearly all the pioneers of the Western country. And although as we have just stated, he was frequently elevated by the free choice of his fellow citizens to posts of honor and importance, yet he was remarkably plain and unassuming in his manners; and however dark the future appeared to others, he was ever hopeful, ever cheerful.
He was buried by the Masons of Monroe Lodge, with all the ceremonies of that ancient order, with which he had been connected nearly forty years. The interment was in a private family burying ground in the orchard planted with his own hands. He was followed to his last resting place by an unusual number of actual descendants. Twelve out of the thirteen were there, the sons with their wives and the daughters with their husbands, and besides he was mourned by a large number of grand children and great grand children.
Col. Okey had the most unyielding faith in the final happiness of all mankind, and no one ever entered more cheerfully on his <<<<<<< HEAD journey to that undiscovered country from whose bourn no traveler returns. We had the pleasure of seeing and conversing with him the day previous to his , and we found him gently sinking to rest, as a tired child sinks into sleep on its mothers lap. Thus full of years and of honors, was he gathered to his fathers. May our last end be like his. Woodsfield September 28th 1859.     W. P. R.
======= journey to that undiscovered country from whose bourn no traveler returns. We had the pleasure of seeing and conversing with him the day previous to his , and we found him gently sinking to rest, as a tired child sinks into sleep on its mother s lap. Thus full of years and of honors, was he gathered to his fathers. May our last end be like his. Woodsfield September 28th 1859. W. P. R. >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711

 Orange, Wilbert ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Orange, Wilbert >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 H.
Source: Times Recorder . . . Zanesville, OH . . Feb 2002
Provided by Betty Lendon Matson
            ZANESVILLE ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> ZANESVILLE >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 -- Wilbert H. Orange, 95, of Zanesville, Ohio died at 1:05 p.m. Thursday, February 14, 2002 at Genesis Hospice, Morrison House.
            Mr. ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Mr. >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Orange was born September 24, 1906, at Monroe County, the son of the late Leonard and Nellie Wallace Orange. He was a retired cost accountant at the former McGraw Edison Co., a member of the Norval Park Church of Christ, and an Army Veteran of World War II.
            Surviving are a sister, Gertrude Fountain of Zanesville, and eight nieces.
            Besides ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Surviving are a sister, Gertrude Fountain of Zanesville, and eight nieces.
Besides >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 his parents, he was preceded in death by his wife, Eva L. Orange, who died November 26, 1996; a sister, Olive Kellow; and a brother, Flavil L. Orange.
            Calling ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Calling >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 hours will be 2 to 4 and 6 to 8 p.m. today at the Bolin Funeral Home, 1271 Blue Ave., with funeral services at 1 p.m. Saturday with Evangelist Dallas Lockhart officiating. Burial will follow at Zanesville Memorial Park

Osovich , James H. "Lottie" , 91, of Neffs, Ohio, died Saturday, February 20, 2005 in Belmont Community Hospital, Bellaire, Ohio.
 He was born ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> He was born >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 January 10, 1914 in Lafferty, Ohio, a son of the late Andrew and Bernice Lopachinski Osovich.
He was retired from the former Hannibal Coal Company, <<<<<<< HEAD a member of the P.N.A  Lodge and a ======= a member of the P.N.A Lodge and a >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Catholic by faith.
He was preceded in death by his wife, Ann Smutylo Osovich, two brothers, Stanley and Mike Osovich, two sisters, Carolyn Hegedus and Jean Klimek.
Surviving are a son, James J. Osovich Jr. of Belmont, Ohio, two daughters, Barbara (Bill) Huntington of Waverly, Ohio and Kay (John) Bradley of Jacksonville, North Carolina; two brothers, Charles of Toledo and John (Rose) Osovich of Bridgeport;eight grandchildren and ten great grandchildren.
 
 At James' ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> At James' >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 request, there will be no visitation. A memorial service will be held at the convenience of the family.
Interment in Mount Calvary Cemetery, Bellaire, Ohio.
Arrangements by Bauknecht-Altmeyer Funeral Homes and Crematory, 441-37th Street, Bellaire, Ohio 43906.

 Otto, Pearl M. Fordyce                                                                                Source--Wheeling News Register     Wheeling, West Virginia                                      Published-- March 21, 1982
            Pearl ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Otto, Pearl M. Fordyce Source--Wheeling News Register Wheeling, West Virginia Published-- March 21, 1982
Pearl >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 M. Fordyce Otto, 85, of 411 Second Street, Marietta, formerly of Woodsfield, died Sunday in Christian Anchorage Nursing Home, Marietta. She was a member of the Woodsfield Church of the Nazarene. She was preceded in death by her husband, John N. Otto in 1960. Surviving are a son, Keith of Ocean, New Jersey; three daughters, Virginia Dowling of New Orleans, Helen Wheeler of Marietta and Dorothy Kenney of Middleport, Ohio; eight grandchildren; six great- grandchildren. Friends received at the Woodsfield Church of the Nazarene, where services will be held at 2:30 p.m. Wednesday. Interment in Oaklawn Cemetery, Woodsfield. Arrangements by the McClure-Shafer Funeral Home, Marietta.
 
Otto, Sharon Ann, nee Patrone
Source-- Times Leader     Martins Ferry, Ohio
Published--September 11, 2004                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       
            Sharon ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Martins Ferry, Ohio
Published--September 11, 2004
Sharon >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Ann Gust Otto, 49, of 379 Rosser Avenue, Bellaire, died Thursday, Sept. 9, 2004 in Bellaire, Ohio. She was born Dec. 30, 1954 in Brooklyn, N.Y., a daughter of Margaret Talkington Patrone and the late Samuel Patrone.She was a member of VFW Post 626 Auxiliary, Bellaire and a Catholic by faith. She was preceded in death by a brother, Frank Allen Patrone. Surviving in addition to her mother, a resident of Bellaire, is a son, Drake Gust of Powhatan Point, Ohio, her companion, Larry Furbee, a brother, Richard (Rosemary) Patrone of Baltimore, Maryland; a sister, Rose Patrone of Bellaire and two nephews. Friends received Friday, 2 to 4 p.m., and 6 to 8 p.m., at the Bauknecht-Altmeyer Funeral Homes and Crematory, 186 Main Street, Powhatan Point, Ohio, where services will be held 1 p.m., Saturday, with Pastor Donald Lawson, Jr., officiating. Interment in Powhatan Cemetery, Powhatan Point, Ohio. Memorial contributions may be made to Sharon Gust Otto Trust, c/o United Bank, Bellaire, Ohio 43906. Online condolences may be expressed to the family at www.altmeyer.com.
 
 
Owens, Donald & Suzette
Source--Times Leader   ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'>Source--Times Leader >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Martins Ferry, Ohio
Published--September 27, 2004
            Shadyside, ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Shadyside, >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Ohio -- Mr. and Mrs. Donald Owens will celebrate their 60th wedding anniversary September 27. They were united in marriage September 27, 1944 in the 7th Regiment Chapel at Fort George G. Meade, Maryland., with Army Chaplain Reverend. Roy L. Yund officiating. Owen is the son of the late Dorcas Owens. He is a retired lineman from the Ohio Power Company in Bellaire. His wife is the former Suzette (Sue) Helms, daughter of the late Blaine and Anna Helms. The couple met at Fort Meade where Don served in the Army during World War II, and Sue was employed there in the Civil Service Branch as a clerk-typist in the Motor Pool Division of the Consolidated Property office. They are parents of three children, Robert Owens and his wife Eearlene of Woodsfield, Sandra Owens Abanathie, deceased, and Don Kevin Owens and his wife Michele of Pickerington. They also have five granddaughers, Carolanne and Sara Abanathie of Turlock, Calif. and Erica and Tori Lloyd and Alexa Owens of Pickerington.They will celebrate with a family dinner at a later date.

            Surviving ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Surviving >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 are his wife, Joyce, with whom he would have celebrated 49 years of marriage this November; three daughters, Mrs. Ed (Debbie) MIller, Jerusalem, Emily Stenger, Massillon, Mrs. Scott (Julie) Bates, Quaker City; son Thomas Pachuta, Canton; sister, Mrs. Joseph (Mary) Kozar, Lore CIty; brother, Andrew and his wife, Evelyn Pachuta, East Sparta; six grandchildren, Angie, Sheila and Todd Miller, Anna Pachuta, Jenna Stenger and Amanda Bates.

Palmer, Georgia Mae Rice
Source:The Herald - Sharon PA - 1997
Provided by Betty Lendon Matson
            Georgia ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Georgia >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Mae Rice Palmer, South Shenango Street, Mercer, died unexpectedly at 12:06 a.m. today (8-11-97) in Horizon Hospital System, Greenville. She was 77.
            Mrs. ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Mrs. >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Palmer was born Aug. 6, 1920, in Franklin to Burris Washington and Mary Ellen Blair Rice.
            She ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> She >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 retired from Mercer County Living Center, Coolspring Township; and the State Regional Correction Facility at Mercer.
            She ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> She >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 was a member and deacon of Bethany Presbyterian Church, Mercer, and beLonged to its Day Timers organization.
            Mrs. ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Mrs. >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Palmer was a member of Brandy Springers, Mercer; and the Organ Club, a music club of Valley Organ, hermitage.
            She ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> She >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 was a winner of several aWards for her oil paintings and was renouned for her organ and piano playing throughout the valley.
            Surviving ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Surviving >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 are: her husband, Kenneth Eugene Palmer Sr., whom she married July 14, 1937; a daughter, Mary Ellen Davey, Sharpsville; two sons, Kenneth E. Jr., Oil City; and David G., Woodsfield, Ohio; a brother, Gene Rice, Seneca, Pa.; a twin brother, George Rice, Lenexa, Ks.; three sisters, Mrs. Bernard (Mildred) Neal, Slippery Rock; Mrs. James (Beula) Jones, New Wilmington; and Gladys Corner, Cochranton; nine grandchildren; and six great-grandchildren.
            She ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> She >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 was preceded in death by four brothers, Paul, Harold, Budd and Jack Rice; and a sister, Mable Martin.

Partlow, Patrick S.

July 20, 1972

DEATH

Patrick S. Partlow

Source: Beacon

 

   Patrick S. Partlow, 52, of Quaker ======= JA'> Patrick S. Partlow, 52, of Quaker >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 City Route 1, formerly of Woodsfield, died Monday evening, July 17, 1972 in Barnesville Hospital after a brief illness.

   Born March 17, 1920, in Wisconsin, ======= JA'> Born March 17, 1920, in Wisconsin, >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 he was a son of the late Frank Partlow and Mrs. Glayds Partlow Sargent, in Tennessee.

   Mr. Partlow was owner and manager ======= JA'> Mr. Partlow was owner and manager >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 of a resort area at Seneca Lake. He was a navy veteran of WWII.

   Surviving are his wife, Mary ======= JA'> Surviving are his wife, Mary >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Kessler Partlow; one son, Gary Partlow of Woodsfield; four daughters, Mrs. Clyde (Terry) Rubel of Lewisville; Mrs. William (Sanda) Dennison II of Woodsfield; Mrs. Wayne (Patricia) Gibson of Dayton and Mrs. Macon (Kathryn) Hare, Jr., of Bogota, Columbia in South America; nine grandchildren; two brothers, Frank Partlow in California and Blake Partlow of Lansing Michigan; and four sisters, Mrs. Clover Boyer in Minnesota; Mrs. Fay Leonard in Michigan; Mrs. Sibyl Haught and Mrs. Mary Sargent, both in Tennessee.

   One son, Keith S. Partlow preceded ======= JA'> One son, Keith S. Partlow preceded >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 him in death April 17, 1967.

   Friends will be received at the ======= JA'> Friends will be received at the >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Gardner Funeral Home after six o'clock Wednesday evening.

   Funeral services will be held at ======= JA'> Funeral services will be held at >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 the funeral home on Friday afternoon at one o'clock. Burial will be in Oaklawn Cemetery.

 
Patchen, Popp, Elsie R., nee Patchen
Published--January 2003
    Popp, Elsie ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Popp, Elsie >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 R., 86, Caldwell, died January 6, 2003, at her residence. She was born September 29, 1916, in Buffalo, N.Y., a daughter of the late Raymond "Jimmy" and Mary Sass Patchen.
    She was a homemaker and a former member of St. Sylvester Catholic Church, Woodsfield.
    Surviving are a daughter,  Thelma Moss, Dexter, New Mexico;  son John "Jack" McQueary, New Martinsville;  two sisters; ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> She was a homemaker and a former member of St. Sylvester Catholic Church, Woodsfield.
Surviving are a daughter, Thelma Moss, Dexter, New Mexico; son John "Jack" McQueary, New Martinsville; two sisters; >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 15 grandchildren, Jay, Lynn, John, Michele, Shawn, Philip, Vincent, Yvonne, Matthew, Francis, Carla, Thaddeus, Kenneth, Gordon and Lydia.
    In addition ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> In addition >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 to her parents, she was preceded in death by her husband, Francis Popp; two sisters.
    Friends will ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Friends will >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 be received at McVay-Perkins Funeral Home, Caldwell, January 8, from 10a.m. until time of services at 2 p.m. with Brother Philip Tardif officiating. Burial will be held at the convenience of the family.

Patterson, Clara
Source:Miscellaneous Early Indiana Obituaries
Provided by Betty Lendon Matson
Brown County Democrat May 10, 1928 CLARA PATTERSON Died Thursday at her home in Nashville. She was born in Woodsfield, Ohio in 1854. She married Samuel Patterson in 1873 on Weed Patch Hill, Brown County. They had five children, 2 children are deceased. surv. are Mrs. Charles Bradley, Indpls., Fred and Guy Patterson, both of Nashville,. Also surv. are 4 nieces, Blanch Guthrie, Los Angeles, Calif., Clara Farmer, Clinton, Ill., Ethel Collins of Indpls. & Bessie Tower, Tenn. and six nephews, Cecil & Foy Watts of Woodriver, Ill., Irvin & Robert N. Guthrie of Indpls., Ira Guthrie of Chicago & John Guthrie of Calif. Also surv. are several cousins: Mrs. Jennie Allison, Ella Durnal, Lennie Holh (sic. Hol), Josephine Stevens, Laura Donaldson, Wm. Hoy, Everett Hoy, Joe Hoy of Delvan, Ill., Juanita Hoy of Indpls., Mary Hoy of Indpls., Lowell Hoy of Indpls. and Lon Burton of Columbus.

Paulus, Chester E.

March 18, 1954

IN THE SERIVE

Source: Monroe County Beacon

   Pfc. Chester E. Paulus, son of Mr. ======= JA'> Pfc. Chester E. Paulus, son of Mr. >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 and Mrs. Chester R. Paulus, of Woodsfield, Route 3, who is in the Far East is stationed in Pusan, Korea, with the 34th Infantry Division. The picture was taken when he was home on furlough having finished his basic training. He would enjoy hearing from his many friends. His address is: Pfc. Chester E. Paulus, U.S. 52-272-127, Company F, 34th Infantry Regiment, APO 24, Care of Postmaster, San Francisco, California.

Paulus, Francis Paulus, 73

     Francis Joseph Paulus, 73, of ======= JA'> Francis Joseph Paulus, 73, of >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Route 1, Woodsfield died at 12:57 pm. Friday, December 12, 1986 in the Marietta Memorial Hospital following a brief illness.

     He was born near Woodsfield on ======= JA'> He was born near Woodsfield on >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 December 13, 1912 a son of the late Joseph and Margaret Schumacher Paulus.

      Mr. Paulus was founder of the Paulus Insurance Agency, Woodsfield representing Grange Mutual and other companies for 35 years.  He was a former committeeman on the Monroe County A.S.C.S., a member of the St. Sylvesters ======= JA'> Mr. Paulus was founder of the Paulus Insurance Agency, Woodsfield representing Grange Mutual and other companies for 35 years. Paulus, Susan Jane and Larry Dale Stephens
Source--Monroe County Beacon    Woodsfield, Ohio
Published-- July 1976      
 
======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Woodsfield, Ohio
Published-- July 1976
>>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711
The Reverend Charles Holmes, of Cuyahoga Falls, officiated for the wedding of Miss Susan Jane Paulus and Larry Dale Stephens on <<<<<<< HEAD Saturday, July  tenth, at two o'clock in ======= Saturday, July tenth, at two o'clock in >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 the afternoon.
The altar of the Oak Chapel United Methodist Church, Wooster, was decorated with one large arrangement of white flowers. White satin bows marked the family pews.
Parents of the couple are Mr. and Mrs. Francis E. Paulus, of Wooster, Route 6, and Mrs. Marie Stephens, of Graysville, and John Stephens of Woodsfield.
A half  hour of ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'>A half hour of >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 traditional music was played by Thomas Mykrantz, organist, prior to thr double-ring ceremony.
The bride, given in marriage by her father, wore a gown of polyester organza over taffeta. Venice lace daisies were scattered over the sheer bishop sleeves and the A-line skirt that swept to a lace bordered chapel train. The empire bodice and U-neckline were trimmed in Venice Lace and pearls. Her camelot cap of Venice lace held a lace-bordered veil of illusion. The bride carried a colonial bouquet of yellow sweetheart roses, miniture white carnations, baby's breath and ivy streamers.
The bride wore a cross necklace which had belonged to her great-grandmother and which had been worn by many family members on special occasions. It had been brought from Wisconsin by the bride's great aunt, Mrs. Laura Gillis.
Miss Glenda Dillon, maid of honor, wore a gown of yellow chiffon knit over taffeta featuring a square neckline edged in Venice lace that dipped to a V-effect in back. The gathered empire bodice featured short puffed sleeves, edged in lace and a self-ruffle. Long streamers tied at the waist of the softly gathered skirt. Her Venice lace camelot cap featured a face veil. Wearing identical gown, only in blue, were bridesmaids, Miss  Mary Paulus, Mrs. Sam Paulus and Miss Debra ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Mary Paulus, Mrs. Sam Paulus and Miss Debra >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Flannagan.
Flower girl, Miss Leeanna Truax. wore a polyester double knit gown in a yellow and blue floral print. Each of the attendants carried a white basket filled with yellow and white daisy pompoms, pink miniature carnations, blue delphiniiums and ivy streamers.
Serving as best man was Richard Truax. Ushers were Sam Paulus, John Stephens and Edward Cicconetti. Timmy Payne was ring bearer.
Mrs. Paulus attended her daughter's wedding in a long blue polyester gown with sheer sleeves. Mrs. Stevens chose a long green gown of polyester with sheer sleeves. Each wore a corsage of double cream cymbidium orchids.
Approximately 150 guests attended the reception held at the church. Covering the bride's table was a white skirt accented with yellow, blue and white bells. Yellow roses and blue carnations decorated the three tiered cake which was flanked with floral arrangements similar to those carried by the attendants.
Hostesses were: Mrs. Richard Truax, Mrs. David Paulus and Mrs. Larry Keylor. Registering guests was Miss Debra Stephens . Aides were:Miss Dana Ryland, Miss Jane Becker, Mrs. Ken Speelman and Mrs. Carolyn Stephens.
The bride changed to a blue polyester and cotton pantsuit when the couple left for a wedding trip to the southern part of Ohio. The couple will reside at Woodsfield.
The bride graduated in 1976 from Northwestern High School and Wayne County Joint Vocational School.
The bridegroom , a 1972 graduate of Skyvue High School in Graysville, is employed by North American Coal Corporation in Clarington.
The rehearsal dinner was held Friday evening at Our Place Resturant in Wooster.
The bride had been honored by a shower hosted by Mary Paulus, Deb Flannagan, Glenda Dillon and Peg Speelman.
Guests attended fro cities in Washington, Wisconsin, Pennsylvania and Ohio.
 
 Paulus, Paulus, >>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 w:st="on">Terry Alan
. Zanesville High School, class of 1981. What lies behind us and what lies before us are tiny matters compared to what lies within us. As Memories unfold across the meadows of our mind, we remember the special moments we shared with others. We would now like to share the moment of Our Graduation with you on May thirty-first at eight o'clock at the John D. Sulsberger Memorial Stadium. Source: High School graduation invitation.
 
Pauluus, Virginia

Published--August 25, 2004
            Marie Sedar, 79, of 17396 Fox Street, Redford, Michigan, formerly of Powhatan Point, Ohio, died Monday, Aug. 23, 2004 in Lavonia, Michigan. Marie was born Oct. 2, 1924 in Dilles Bottom, Ohio, a daughter of the late Mike and Smelia Kukich Pavich.  She was Senior Life Underwriter with League Life Insurance Company of Southfield, Michigan. She was a Presbyterian by faith.She was preceded in death by a brother,  Thomas Pavich . Surviving are her husband, ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Marie Sedar, 79, of 17396 Fox Street, Redford, Michigan, formerly of Powhatan Point, Ohio, died Monday, Aug. 23, 2004 in Lavonia, Michigan. Marie was born Oct. 2, 1924 in Dilles Bottom, Ohio, a daughter of the late Mike and Smelia Kukich Pavich. She was Senior Life Underwriter with League Life Insurance Company of Southfield, Michigan. She was a Presbyterian by faith.She was preceded in death by a brother, Thomas Pavich . Surviving are her husband, >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Mathew Serdar, a daughter, Janis Bunnell and her husband, Brent, of Lancaster, Pa., four grandchildren, Kristen Bunnell, Daniel Bunnell, Mark Bunnell and Kimberly Bunnell; two brothers, Mike (Meg) Pavich and Donald (Janet) Pavich, all of Columbus, a sister, Olga (James) Roberts of Welches, Oregon, an Uncle Nick (Rose) Kukich of Claymont, Delaware; several nieces and nephews.        Friends received Friday, 2 to 4 and 6 ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Friends received Friday, 2 to 4 and 6 >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 to 8 p.m., at the Bauknecht-Altmeyer Funeral Homes and Crematory, 186 Main Street, Powhatan Point, Ohio, where funeral services will be held 11 a.m., Saturday, with Rev. Rick Hendrix officiating. Interment in Powhatan Cemetery, Powhatan Point, Ohio. Memorial contributions may be made to Angela Hospice, 14100 Newburgh Road, Lavonia, Michigan 48154-5010.

Pekari, Miss Bertha and Mr. Frank E. Schumacher
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs., May 17, 1917
               On Wednesday morning at 5:30 oclock, May 16, 1917, at St. Johns Catholic Church at Miltonsburg, Ohio was ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> On Wednesday morning at 5:30 o clock, May 16, 1917, at St. John s Catholic Church at Miltonsburg, Ohio was >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 solemnized the marriage of Mr. Frank E. SCHUMACHER of Woodsfield and Miss Bertha PEKARI of Miltonsburg. The ceremony was performed by the Reverend MILLER, pastor of the Church at that place. After the ceremony a bountiful wedding breakfast was served at the home of the bride and the happy couple left for a wedding trip to some of the large cities of the East. The bride is an accomplished young lady and enjoys the respect of the people of her neighborhood; the groom is a young business man of Woodsfield and is well known as an upright gentleman. We extend congratulations and wish them many years of happy married life.
 
Penn, Margaret
 
May 7, 1841
 
October 10, 1921, residence: Woodsfield

Perkins, James C.
SOURCE: Daily Jeffersonian . . . Cambridge, OH . . October 2001 . .
            BETHESDA  James C. Perkins, 82, of Beallsville, died Sunday (Oct. 14, 2001) at Park ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> BETHESDA James C. Perkins, 82, of Beallsville, died Sunday (Oct. 14, 2001) at Park >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Health Care Center, St. Clairsville.
He was born Oct. 15, 1918, in Belmont, son of the late Charles and Nora (Beckett) Perkins.
Mr. Perkins was a member of Beallsville First Christian Church.
He retired from Ormet Corp. following 25 years of service. He was also a retired farmer and for a time he served as Beallsville Village street commissioner.
He was preceded in death by a sister, Edna Burkhart.
He leaves his wife of 63 years, Marie (McFarland) Perkins; four daughters, Mrs. Stanley (Wanda) Jarrett of Beallsville, Mrs. Lewis (Jean) Wharton of Urbana, Mrs. Don (Vera) White of Bethesda and Wilda Perkins of Beallsville; a son, Lowell (Lisa) Perkins of St. Clairsville; 11 grandchildren, Theresa Edmondson of Jacobsburg, Paula Kuthy of Kimbolton, Julie Mellinger of Centerville, Lisa Swallie of Belmont, Kasi Deppen of Urbana, Kala and Larissa Perkins of St. Clairsville, Kevin Jarrett of Newark, Rick and Terry Jarrett of Beallsville and Jon Perkins of St. Clairsville; 13 great-grandchildren; and a sister, Virginia LaFaber of Beallsville.
Friends may call from 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 p.m. today at Kelly-Kemp-Braido Funeral Home, Bethesda, where services will be 11 a.m. Wednesday with Minister Wayne Clark officiating. Burial will be in Holly Memorial Gardens.

Perkins, Marvin and Alice, nee Graham
            Beallsville, Ohio -  Marvin and Alice Perkins are ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Beallsville, Ohio - Marvin and Alice Perkins are >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 celebrating their 45th wedding annversary today, July 3. They were united in marriage in 1959 at Armstrongs Mills with William Foster officiating.
Perkins is the son of the late Kenneth and Ruth (Day) Perkins. His wife Alice (Graham) is the daughter of the late George and Goldia Graham.
The couple has four sons, Chris and wife Nellie of Alledonia, Eric and wife Deana of Somerton, Brent and wife Lori of Urbana, and Darrel and wife Julie of Belmont.
The couple has nine grandchildren: Crystal and Hannah of Alledonia, Justin, Aaron and Nathan, all of Somerton, Andrew and Jonah of Urbana, Lane and Marissa of Belmont. They also have two step-grandchildren, Chelsea and Cami Westfall of Cecilia, Ky.
Source--The Times Leader, Martins Ferry, Ohio, July 7, 2004

Pfalzgraf, Anna Marie Bintz X
    Anna Marie Pfalzgraf Bintz, a daughter of George and Sophia Kilburn Pfalzgraf, was born in Seneca township, Monroe County, Ohio, October 31, 1884. She was brought up and confirmed in the German Evangelical Church known as St. Johns Middle Church, of Summit township, Lewisville, Ohio.
  On February 2, 1909, she was married to Elmer Bintz. Five children were born, all girls.
  Anna Marie was ill with tuberculosis of lungs in 1916. She went to Mt. Vernon to a sanitarium for some time, but her mothers love for her dear children was more than she ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Anna Marie Pfalzgraf Bintz, a daughter of George and Sophia Kilburn Pfalzgraf, was born in Seneca township, Monroe County, Ohio, October 31, 1884. She was brought up and confirmed in the German Evangelical Church known as St. John s Middle Church, of Summit township, Lewisville, Ohio.
On February 2, 1909, she was married to Elmer Bintz. Five children were born, all girls.
Anna Marie was ill with tuberculosis of lungs in 1916. She went to Mt. Vernon to a sanitarium for some time, but her mother s love for her dear children was more than she >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 could stand getting homesick for them she came home again in Malaga township, after about six weeks of absence, though apparently much improved, but only for a short time. She gradually grew worse till on the morning of July 4, 1919.
  She leaves to ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> She leaves to >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 mourn her devoted husband and five small children, father and mother, three sisters and one brother, besides a large number of near relatives and friends.
  Services were conducted by the Reverend S. E. Kaetzel, of Clarington, Ohio.
  Burial was made in the German M. E. cemetery near Monroefield, Ohio on Sunday morning July 6, 1919.             Source: Newspaper ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Services were conducted by the Reverend S. E. Kaetzel, of Clarington, Ohio.
Burial was made in the German M. E. cemetery near Monroefield, Ohio on Sunday morning July 6, 1919. Source: Newspaper >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 clipping July 1919
 
1950
Pfalzgraf,Benjamin Franklin
             Benjamin Franklin Pfalzgraf, was born near Lewisville, Ohio on August 21, 1890 and departed this life in St. Francis Hospital, Cambridge, Ohio, on Thursday night, March 10, 1950, at 12 oclock. He ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Benjamin Franklin Pfalzgraf, was born near Lewisville, Ohio on August 21, 1890 and departed this life in St. Francis Hospital, Cambridge, Ohio, on Thursday night, March 10, 1950, at 12 o clock. He >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 was 59 years, 7 months, and 13 days of age. He spent his entire life in the Lewisville community.
 Mr. Pfalzgraf had been in failing health nearly eight months.
 On December 25, 1906 he was confirmed in St. Johns Evangelical and Reformed Church, Middle ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Mr. Pfalzgraf had been in failing health nearly eight months.
On December 25, 1906 he was confirmed in St. John s Evangelical and Reformed Church, Middle >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Church, near Lewisville. He was united in marriage with Isabelle Barrett on May 2, 1931, and to this union three children were born, Minnie, George, and Hazel.
 Besides his ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Besides his >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 wife and children, he leaves three sisters, Mrs. Pauline Bintz, Mrs. Minnie Bintz, and Mrs. Louisa Kahrig. He was preceded in death by his parents and two sisters, Anna and Matilda.
 Services were ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Services were >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 held in his home by the Reverend Floyd Workman. Burial in Oaklawn Cemetery, Woodsfield.
Source:Newspaper clipping , March 1950
Collection of Gertrude Christman Kahrig
1930 Ohio Census:
  Benjamin F. ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Benjamin F. >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 was 39 yrs. old, born abt. 1891 in Ohio.
His father was born in Ohio and his mother in Kentucky. He was single. He
could read, write and speak English. He was a laborer on a general farm,
earning wages. He lived with his parens, George and Sophia, and sister,
Pauline, in Seneca Twp., Monroe Co., Ohio. Provided by Becky Graham Stephenson
 
Pfalzgraf, Benjamin F.

In Memoriam

     In loving memory of our dear husband and father, ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> In loving memory of our dear husband and father, >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Benjamin F. Pfalzgraf, who passed away five years ago, March 10, 1950.

Pfalzgraf, Caroline (nee Bintz)
               Caroline Bintz Pfalzgraf was born ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> Caroline Bintz Pfalzgraf was born >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 April 27, 1837, the daughter of George Jacob and Maria Elizabeth Kindelberger Bintz; died April 15, 1912; spouse Jacob Pfalzgraf; parents of nine children.

Pfalzgraf, Claremont C.

February 20, 1975

90th BIRTHDAY

Clarement Pfalzgraf  

   Woodsfield, Ohio- Claremont ======= JA'>Clarement Pfalzgraf

Woodsfield, Ohio- Claremont >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Pfalzgraf, who was born February 28, 1885, at Rockport, West Virginia, will celebrate his 90th birthday February 28, 1975.

   He has been a resident of ======= JA'> He has been a resident of >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Rockport, West Virignia, 26169, all his life. His life was spent farming, with a period of five years with the Mountain State Steel Foundry Company, Parkersburg, West Virginia.

   He is the father of six children - ======= JA'> He is the father of six children - >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 five of the living at the present time. Harold, Raymond, Robert, Rex Pfalzgarf and Mary Post.

   A birthday party will be held in ======= JA'> A birthday party will be held in >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 his honor on Sunday, March 2, 1975, in the Masonic Temple, 900 Market Street, Parkersburg, West Virginia between the hours of 1:30 and 4:00 p.m. Friends and relatives are invited to be present. In lieu of presents, he would appreciate cards from his many friends and relatives.

Pfalzgraf, Claremont C.
            Claremont Pfalzgraf, date of birth ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Claremont Pfalzgraf, date of birth >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 February 28, 1885; departed this life November 2, 1976; services Rockport United Methodist Church on November 6, 1976, Saturday at 2:00 p.m.; clergyman officiating Reverend Paul Knierim; interment Limestone Cemetery; arrangements by Leavitt Funeral Home on 403 Seventh Street in Parkersburg, West Virginia.
Source:Memory card. Collection of Beryl Christman Claus
 
Pfalzgraf, Edith

Pfalzgraf, Forrest D.
   Forrest D. ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Forrest D. >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Pfalzgraf, a representative and successful attorney of Monroe County, with office in the Monroe Bank Building at Woodsfield, was elected in November, 1936, to the office of prosecuting attorney of Monroe County. He is a native son of this county born at Beallsville, May 22, 1901. His parents, John W. and Amanda (Walton) Pfalzgraf, are both natives of Cameron, Monroe County, Ohio, and reside on a farm near Clarington which the father has cultivated throughout his active career. The great-grandfather in the paternal line crossed the Atlantic to the United States from Germany, locating on a farm on Willis creek, in Seneca township, Monroe County, Ohio, which is still in possession on his son, a great-uncle of F.D. Pfalzgraf. John Pfalzgraf, grandfather of our subject, found in the Civil War and was active in repelling Morgan's raid through this section of Ohio. He followed the occupation of farming as a life work, served as commissioner of Monroe County for two terms and was also a director other County Infirmary. The forebears of F.D. Pfalzgraf in the maternal line came to Monroe County, Ohio, from New England in an early day, and among the male members of the family were representatives of the professions as well as agriculturists. Richard Walter served on the bench as judge of the Probate Court of Monroe County.
   Forrest D. ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Forrest D. >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Pfalzgraf pursued his education in the schools of Clarington and Woodsfield and completed his high school course by graduation with the class of 1920. During the succeeding decade he taught school and while thus engaged also attended Ohio University at Athens, Ohio, Ohio State University at Columbus, and the Ohio Northern University at Ada, receiving the degree of Bachelor of Laws from the last named institution in 1929, when he was graduated with the second highest honors of his class. He began the practice of law at Logan, Ohio, in 1929 but a year later removed to Hannibal, Monroe County, where he engaged in teaching and maintained as office in Woodsfield, where he is accorded a gratifying clientele that is steadily growing in volume and importance. He has membership in the Monroe County Bar Association and fraternally is identified with the Independent Order of Odd Fellows, while his religious faith is that of the Methodist Episcopal church, in which he has taught a Sunday school class for several years. His political support is given to the Democratic party.
 
   In August, ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> In August, >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 1924, Mr. Pfalzgraf married Grace M. McFarland, who was born in August, 1901, a daughter of Etson O., and Ophelia (Clagg) McFarland, natives of Monroe County, Ohio, where her father has followed farming for many years. Mr. and Mrs. Pfalzgraf have four children: Evelyn, born in August, 1925; Joyce Jean, born in August, 1930; Doris, born in August, 1932, and Grace, born in December 1933.
 
[Source: Ohio: A Four-Volume Reference Library on the History of A Great State, Chicago: Lewis Publishing Co., 1937, p. 303-304; obtained from Heritage Quest]
 
Pfalzgraf, Fred
April 27, 1911
October 1985
 

Fred Pfalzgraf

     Fred S. Pfalzgraf, 74, of Clarington, died Oct. 12 at his home.  He ======= JA'> Fred S. Pfalzgraf, 74, of Clarington, died Oct. 12 at his home. He >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 was born April 27, 1911, at Cameron, a son of the late Samuel and Emma Mellot Pfalzgraf.

     A retired Monroe County ======= JA'> A retired Monroe County >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 businessman, he was a member of the Church of Christ, Cameron, the Sunsbury Lodge No. 362 F&A.M. of Beallsville, the Scottish Rite Valley of Columbus, Order of Eastern Star Chapter No. 533 of Clarington, Ohio and Monroe County Retired Teachers Association, and a former member of the Monroe County Board of Education.

     Preceding him in death were two ======= JA'> Preceding him in death were two >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 brothers, John Pfalzgraf in 1952 and Paul Pfalzgraf in 1946; a sister, Mary Blachly in 1985.

     Surviving are his wife, Ethel ======= JA'> Surviving are his wife, Ethel >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Staib Pfalzgraf; a son, Jack Pfalzgraf of Lewisville; a sister, Helen Pfalzgraf of Cameron; three grandchildren; two great-grandchildren.

     Friends were received at the Rush Funeral Home, Clarington, where services were held Oct 15 with the Rev. John Roberson and the Rev. William Lawson officiating.  Burial in Zion Cemetery, Clarington. Source: ======= JA'> Friends were received at the Rush Funeral Home, Clarington, where services were held Oct 15 with the Rev. John Roberson and the Rev. William Lawson officiating. Burial in Zion Cemetery, Clarington. Source: >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 October 17, 1985

Monroe County Beacon, Woodsfield, Ohio

Pfalzgraf, Jack and Miss Shirley Truax

1956

MARRIAGE

Truax-Pfalzgraf

Source: Monroe County Beacon

 

   Miss Shirley Truax, daughter of ======= JA'>

Miss Shirley Truax, daughter of >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Mr. and Mrs. C. L. Truax, of Woodsfield, Route 3, became the bride of Mr. Jack J. Pfalzgraf, son of Mrs. Don Harkins, of Caldwell, and Mr. Fred Pfalzgraf, of Clarington in a quiet church ceremony performed on Sunday, June third, at two o'clock, in the afternoon at the Woodsfield Church of Christ in the presence of relatives and close friends. Rev. Robert Fraley officiated at the double ring ceremony.

   The bride was attired in a ======= JA'> The bride was attired in a >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 ballerina length gown of white bridal satin with matching gloves that came to a point over her hands. She wore a short veil of illusion topped with a tiara of white pearl orange blossoms accented by rhinestones. She carried a cascade bouquet of red and white Rosebuds with white satin streamers. She carried out the tradition of something old, new, borrowed, blue and a penny in her shoe.

   Mrs. Judy Burkhart, maid of honor, ======= JA'> Mrs. Judy Burkhart, maid of honor, >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 wore a ballerina length gown of copen blue satin in princess style. White nylon gloves and a headdress of white flowers completed her attire. She carried a colonial bouquet of white baby mums and light pink carnations.

   Francis Sulsberger, Jr. served Mr. ======= JA'> Francis Sulsberger, Jr. served Mr. >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Pfalzgraf as best man.

   The mother of the bride was ======= JA'> The mother of the bride was >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 attired in a navy blue linen suit trimmed in white with matching accessories and a corsage of red Rosebuds. The mother of the groom was dressed in a rust dress with matching accessories and a corsage of red Rosebuds.

   The church was decorated with ======= JA'> The church was decorated with >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 palms and vases of white mums.

   Immediately following the ======= JA'> Immediately following the >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 ceremony, a reception was held in the Truax Restaurant. The centerpiece for the table was a three-tiered wedding cake topped with a miniature bride and groom.

   The newlyweds are both graduates ======= JA'> The newlyweds are both graduates >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 of Woodsfield High School. Mr. Pfalzgraf is now employed by the Ohio Bell Telephone Company in Bellaire.

   The couple is at home to their friends at Maloney's Trailer Court, Route 1, Bellaire, Ohio.  

======= JA'> The couple is at home to their friends at Maloney's Trailer Court, Route 1, Bellaire, Ohio.

>>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711
 
Pfalzgraf, Jacob
  Jacob ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Jacob >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Pfalzgraf was born in 1833 in Seneca township, Monroe Co.; farmer; married; died in Washington County, Ohio on February 4, 1873; age 39 years, 9 months and 4 days; cause, drowned; spouse, Caroline Bintz; residence was in Center twp., Monroe County; Nine children were born to them; father, George Michael <<<<<<< HEAD Pfalzgraf, Jr.; mother, Elizabeth DIEHL; burial in St. Johns Middle Church cemetery, Lewisville, Ohio. The Spirit of Democracy newspaper in Woodsfield, Ohio, issue February 11, 1873, stated that Jacob Pfalzgraf, of this township, drowned February 4, 1873, after running a raft of logs down a creek with James DRUM of Bloomfield in Washington County, Ohio. The raft ran into Mr. Drums ======= Pfalzgraf, Jr.; mother, Elizabeth DIEHL; burial in St. John s Middle Church cemetery, Lewisville, Ohio. The Spirit of Democracy newspaper in Woodsfield, Ohio, issue February 11, 1873, stated that Jacob Pfalzgraf, of this township, drowned February 4, 1873, after running a raft of logs down a creek with James DRUM of Bloomfield in Washington County, Ohio. The raft ran into Mr. Drum s >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 mill-dam. He leaves wife and several children. The body was found February 7th about 100 yards below the dam.
Source: The Spirit of Democracy, Woodsfield, Ohio, dated February 20, 1873
            An ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> An >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 article regarding the history of the mill dam where Jacob drowned was published in The Spirit of Democracy, Friday, November 19, 1981, and written by Clyde Decker - Jerusalem, Ohio.
            Jacob ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Jacob >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Winland erected a water mill on Sunfish Creek and in the northwest quarter of Center Township's section #31 (T-5, R-5). Stephen Cisne assigned this land to Jacob Winland. The first payment to the government was made, July 5, 1818. The final payment wasn't made until, April 4, 1825, some three and one-half years after Jacob Winland's , and the patent deed was dated, August 25, 1825. This mill was later owned by Jacob Pfalzgraf (1833-February 4, 1873) a son to George Michael, Jr,. (August 24, 1809-January 2, 1867) and Elizabeth (Diehl) Pfalzgraf (July 12, 1808-July 17, 1883). Jacob Pfalzgraf drowned in the mill dam, Thursday, February 4, 1873.

Pfalzgraf, John W.

Death

October 26, 1984

The Daily Jeffersonian, Cambridge, Ohio

 

John W. Pfalzgraf

     Woodsfield  John W. Pfalzgraf, ======= JA'> Woodsfield John W. Pfalzgraf, >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 54, of Wooster, died Wednesday (Oct. 24, 1984) in Akron General Hospital, Akron.

     He was born June 13, 1930, in Clarington, son of Lucy Shaw Pfalzgraf of Clarington R.D. 1 and the late John Pfalzgraf.  He was a veteran of the ======= JA'> He was born June 13, 1930, in Clarington, son of Lucy Shaw Pfalzgraf of Clarington R.D. 1 and the late John Pfalzgraf. He was a veteran of the >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Korean War, a retired employee of Rubbermaid Corp. in Wooster and a member of West Hill Baptist Church, Wooster.

     In addition to his mother, Mr. ======= JA'> In addition to his mother, Mr. >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Pfalzgraf leaves his wife, Deli Hawkins Pfalzgraf; two daughters, Mrs. John (Diane) Maki of Orrville and Mrs. Greg (Pattie) Still of Wooster; three brothers, Edward and James, both of Clarington, and Kenneth of Wooster; four sisters, Mrs. Raymond (Genevieve) Agnew and Mrs. Donald (Dorothy) Klein, both of Stow, Mrs. Charles (Shirley) Clegg of Sardis and Mrs. William (Carol) Patterson of Shreve; and a grandson.

     Friends may call 7 to 9 p.m. ======= JA'> Friends may call 7 to 9 p.m. >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 today at MacIntire Funeral Home in Wooster and from noon to 2:30 p.m. Saturday at the Bauer-Turner Funeral Home in Woodsfield, where services will be 2:30 p.m. Saturday. Burial will be in Chapel Hill Cemetery, Clarington.

Pfalzgraf, lemuel Alexander

Thursday, July 20, 1944

The Monroe County Beacon, Woodsfield, Ohio

L.A. Pfalzgraf Dies At Parkersburg

     Many relatives in Monroe county were saddened to hear of the death of Lemuel Alexander Pfalzgraf in Parkersburg, W. Va., late Thursday evening, July 13, 1944.  Death followed an operation for appendicitis which he had undergone the preceding Tuesday.  Mr. Pfalzgraf was born in Rockport, W. Va., in June 1881 and was a son of the late Lewis and Elizabeth Miller Pfalzgraf, both natives of Monroe county.  For 25 years Mr. Pfalzgraf was a ======= JA'> Many relatives in Monroe county were saddened to hear of the death of Lemuel Alexander Pfalzgraf in Parkersburg, W. Va., late Thursday evening, July 13, 1944. Death followed an operation for appendicitis which he had undergone the preceding Tuesday. Mr. Pfalzgraf was born in Rockport, W. Va., in June 1881 and was a son of the late Lewis and Elizabeth Miller Pfalzgraf, both natives of Monroe county. For 25 years Mr. Pfalzgraf was a >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 school teacher and later held various positions in public office in Wood county.

     Early in life he joined the ======= JA'> Early in life he joined the >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Methodist church at Parkersburg, later transferring to the Rockport Methodist church.

     In addition to his wife, Lucy ======= JA'> In addition to his wife, Lucy >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Pfalzgraf he is survived by three daughters and six grandchildren and the following brother and sisters: C. C. Pfalzgraf and Mrs. Harry McPherson of Rockport, W. Va., and Mrs. Rose Ramsay and Mrs. John Lemons of Parkersburg.

     Funeral services were held at ======= JA'> Funeral services were held at >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 the Warren funeral home in Parkersburg Sunday afternoon and burial was made n Parkersburg.

     Those attending the funeral from ======= JA'> Those attending the funeral from >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Monroe county were: Geo. Pfalzgraf, his aged uncle of Lewisville Route 1; Mr. and Mrs. L. E. Christman, Mr. and Mrs. Wesley Bintz, Mr. and Mrs. Elmer Bintz, of Lewisville R. 1; Mr. Sam Christman and son Grant, of Woodsfield, R. 3; Mr. and Mrs. George M. Christman, of near Miltonsburg; John W. Christman, of Quaker City R.; Dora Claus, of Jerusalem R. 2 and Mrs. John Feldner of Woodsfield.

Pfalzgraf, Lewis Louis

He was born in Monroe County, November 16, 1857, a son of Jacob and Caroline Bintz Pfalzgraf. He left Monroe County with his parents many years ago. He is survived by several children and one brother, John Pfalzgraf. His wife preceded him in death.

Pfalzgraf, Michelle and Anthony Wells

Engagement

     The winner of the pageant will be ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> The winner of the pageant will be >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 announced and officially crowned during the All-Star High School Football Game, Saturday, August 10, at Wheeling Island Stadium.

She is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Pfalzgraf, of Route 1, Clarington.

 

 

 
Pfalzgraf, Saloma

Pfalzgraf, Samuel
October 23, 1875
July 1972
Cameron
 
 

August 3, 1972

DEATH

Pfalzgraf, Samuel E.

Source: Beacon

   Samuel E. Pfalzgraf, 96, a retired ======= JA'> Samuel E. Pfalzgraf, 96, a retired >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Cameron postmaster, merchant and school teacher and local historian, died Wednesday evening, July 26, 1972, at five o'clock at his home in Cameron.

   He was born October 23, 1875, near ======= JA'> He was born October 23, 1875, near >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Cameron, the son of the late John and Catharine Christman Pfalzgraf. He was the last member of a family of eleven children.

   Mr. Pfalzgraf was postmaster at ======= JA'> Mr. Pfalzgraf was postmaster at >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Cameron forty-three years.

   Surviving are his wife, Emma ======= JA'> Surviving are his wife, Emma >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Mellott Pfalzgraf; one son, Fred Pfalzgraf, of Clarington, and two daughters, Mrs. Ray (Mary) Blachly, of Canal Fulton, and Miss Helen Pfalzgraf, of the home.

   One son, Paul Pfalzgraf, was ======= JA'> One son, Paul Pfalzgraf, was >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 killed in the service, and another son John Pfalzgraf, is also deceased.

   Funeral services were held ======= JA'> Funeral services were held >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Saturday afternoon at two o'clock in the Rush Funeral Home at Clarington, with Evangelist Fred Dennis officiating. Interment was in Oaklawn Cemetery, Woodsfield.

======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711
 
         Misty ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Misty >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 D. Pfuehler, age 39, of New Gambier Road, Gambier, passed away on Thursday May 19, 2005 at Riverside Methodist Hospital in Columbus. She was born on May 27, 1965 in Marietta, Ohio, moved to Mount Vernon when she was four years old and was a graduate of Mount Vernon High School. Misty had been employed at TRW in Mount Vernon for the past 17 years. She was a member of the Newark Road Church of Christ. Misty enjoyed spending quality time doing anything with her family and friends. Her passion was her family but Misty had a special love for all of <<<<<<< HEAD Gods animals.
         Besides ======= God s animals.
Besides >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 her parents she is survived by two daughters, Tokala Redman and Rose Redman both of the home, her longtime companion Todd Redman; her mother Beulah Mae (Christman) Lemley of Mount Vernon; her father Phillip Pfuehler of New Madrid, Missouri; 2 brothers Lanny Wayne Snell of Mount Vernon and Danny Hegadorn of North Carolina, three sisters Philanna Pfuehler, Melody McCoy both of Mount <<<<<<< HEAD Vernon and Sandy Brewer of Arkansas; and Todds parents, Robert Dean and Patricia Fay Redman of Newark.
         She was preceded in death by an infant son, Dakota Redman.
         Friends ======= Vernon and Sandy Brewer of Arkansas; and Todd s parents, Robert Dean and Patricia Fay Redman of Newark.
She was preceded in death by an infant son, Dakota Redman.
Friends >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 may call on Monday from 2 to 4 PM and 6 to 8 PM at the Dowds-Snyder Funeral Home in Mount Vernon, where a funeral service will be held Tuesday at 11 AM with Rev. Philip McMurrin officiating. Burial will follow at Mound View Cemetery in Mount Vernon.
         Memorial contributions may be made to the family for the continued education of Mistys children.

THURSDAY, OCT. <<<<<<< HEAD 17, 1974 Page Four      The Monroe County ======= 17, 1974 Page Four The Monroe County >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Beacon, Woodsfield, Ohio

To Celebrate Silver Wedding

Mr. and Mrs. Carl Piatt, of New Matamoras. Route L, will celebrate their silver wedding anniversary, Sunday, October 20, with a family dinner ai their home.

Imogene Cline, daughter of the late William and Grace Cline, and Carl Piatt,

son of Thurman and Phena Piatt, were married October 22, 1949 at Woodsfield by Minister J.V.A. Traylor,

They are the parents of one daughter, Janet Ayers, of Lower Salem. Two grandchildren, Susan and Bonnie Ayers, complete (he family circle.

Piatt, Charles D.
   Charles D. Piatt , 77 , of 39183  CR 13 , Graysville, died at 1:42 p.m., Oct. 28,1995 in The University Hospital, Columbus. He was born at Sycamore Valley on  June 7, 1918, a son of the late Thurman G. and Phena Jane Nalley Piatt.
   He was a ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Charles D. Piatt , 77 , of 39183 CR 13 , Graysville, died at 1:42 p.m., Oct. 28,1995 in The University Hospital, Columbus. He was born at Sycamore Valley on June 7, 1918, a son of the late Thurman G. and Phena Jane Nalley Piatt.
He was a >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 former employee of Republic Steel in Canton, a farmer, and a livestock hauler. He was also a U.S. Army Veteran of World War ll and a Protestant by faith.
   Surviving are his wife, Dora Vess Piatt, whom he married on Dec.16, 1938 ;  four sons and daughter-in-laws,  Denver and Muriel Piatt of Wooster,  Ronald and Marsha Piatt of Mantua ,  Gary and Vivian Piatt , Edwin and Joyce Piatt, all or Graysville;  two sisters, Mabel Dillon and Ruth Lisk of Marietta,Ohio;  three brothers,  Forrest "Ben" and Clarence Emil Piatt of Marietta and Lester L. Piatt of  Whipple; 8 grandchildren ; several great-grandchildren; and several great-great-grandchildren.

Source:Daily Jeffersonian . . . Cambridge, OH . . Aug 2001
Provided by Betty Lendon Matson
            Woodsfield  Lester L. Piatt, 70, of Whipple R.D. 1, died Friday, (August 3, 2001) in Marietta ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Woodsfield Lester L. Piatt, 70, of Whipple R.D. 1, died Friday, (August 3, 2001) in Marietta >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Memorial Hospital, Marietta.
He was born March 4, 1931, near Graysville, son of the late Thurman and Phena Jane (Nalley) Piatt.
            Mr. Piatt was a retired employee of the Airolite Co., Marietta, and a farmer. He attended Whipple Baptist Church; was a U.S. Army veteran of the Korean War; a member of the Aurelius Lodge 0308 F. & A.M., Macksburg; and a member of the Cattlemens Association in Washington County.
            In ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Mr. Piatt was a retired employee of the Airolite Co., Marietta, and a farmer. He attended Whipple Baptist Church; was a U.S. Army veteran of the Korean War; a member of the Aurelius Lodge 0308 F. & A.M., Macksburg; and a member of the Cattlemen s Association in Washington County.
In >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 addition to his parents, he was preceded in death by an infant son, Todd Piatt; five brothers, Harry Piatt, Heber Piatt, Ray Piatt, Charles Piatt and Carl Piatt.
            He leaves his wife, Anna Lee (Carpenter) Piatt, whom he married October 27, 1952; two sons, Jerald (Vikki) Piatt of Whipple; Gale (Pam) Piatt of Bridgeport, W.Va.; two sisters, Mabel Dillon and Ruth (Junior) Lisk, both of Marietta; two brothers, Forrest Ben (Maxine) Piatt and Emil (Anna) Piatt, both of Marietta; ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> He leaves his wife, Anna Lee (Carpenter) Piatt, whom he married October 27, 1952; two sons, Jerald (Vikki) Piatt of Whipple; Gale (Pam) Piatt of Bridgeport, W.Va.; two sisters, Mabel Dillon and Ruth (Junior) Lisk, both of Marietta; two brothers, Forrest Ben (Maxine) Piatt and Emil (Anna) Piatt, both of Marietta; >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 two sister-in-laws, Dora Piatt and Imogene Piatt, both of Graysville; three grandchildren; two step-grandchildren; four great-grandchildren; mother-in-law; and several nieces and nephews.
            Friends ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Friends >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 may call at Watters Funeral Home, 37501 Route 78 West, Woodsfield, from 2 to 4 p.m. and 7 to 9 Tuesday, where services will be at 1 p.m. Wednesday with Pastor Scott Souther officiating.

            GRAYSVILLE ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> GRAYSVILLE >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 -- Mary Piatt, 100, of Ohio 26, Graysville, died Friday (March 30, 2001) at the Monroe County Care Center in Woodsfield. She was born February 9, 1901, in Graysville to Allen and Anna Christy King. She was a homemaker and a member of Graysville United Methodist Church and the Women's Society of the church for many years.
            She ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> She >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 is survived by one daughter, Vera Ullman and her husband, Ralph, of Graysville; two grandchildren, Larry Ullman and his wife, Donna, of Graysville and Karen Marks and her husband, Bob, of Cambridge; three great-grandchildren, Keith Ullman and his wife, Tina, of Graysville, Tammy Howell and her husband, Kevin, of Rinard Mills and Kimberly Marks of Cambridge; and five great-great-grandchildren, Michael and Jonathan Ullman and Latasha, Tyler and Cole Howell.
            She ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> She >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 was preceded in death by her husband of 80 years, Glenn Piatt, on April 13, 2000; one sister, Carrie Moore; and two brothers, Harold and Lloyd King.
            Services ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Services >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 are at 1 p.m. Monday at Bauer-Turner Funeral Home, 100 S. Paul St., Woodsfield, with Pastor Madlynne Webber officiating. Burial is in Oaklawn Cemetery in Woodsfield. Friends will be received from 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 p.m. Sunday at the funeral home.

            He ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Harold Kenney Jr. will officiate.
Burial will be in Pleasant Ridge Cemetery near Graysville.
Friends may call from 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 p.m. today at the funeral home.
He >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 was born July 30, 1936, near Graysville, son of Ethel Smith Piatt of Graysville, and the late Everett R. Piatt.
            He was a former coal miner and construction worker.
            He was preceded in death by a brother, Vic Piatt, in 1973.

Miss Helen Ackerman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Ackerman, north of Woodsfield, and Edward F. Pickens, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Pickens, of Lewisville, Ohio were united in marriage at 7:15 o clock, Saturday evening, February 25th. >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Minister J. V. A. Traylor, pastor of the Woodsfield Church of Christ, officiated at the exchange of marriage vows at his home on Eastern Avenue.

PIERCE, Joseph
 Calais was the scene of an unusual tragedy early Thursday morning.
 The home of ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Calais was the scene of an unusual tragedy early Thursday morning.
The home of >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Joseph Pierce was completely destroyed by fire about 4 o'clock Thursday morning, which Started from an overheated stove pipe. Mr. Pierce arise about 3 o'clock and Started the fire and a little later Mrs. Pierce while preparing breakfast smelled smoke and on going upstairs found the bed afire where the children were sleeping.
 In trying to ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> In trying to >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 save the children, Mrs. Pierce was burned so badly that she died Thursday afternoon. A daughter, Ethel was also burned up her body being found later in the debris. An older brother, Mansel Pierce, broke and upstairs window and threw two children out and also dragged his mother outside.
 Mr. Pierce was ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Mr. Pierce was >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 badly burned and is still unconscious but hopes are held for his recovery. A grandchild is also in serious condition from burns.
 Funeral ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Funeral >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 services for Mrs. Pierce and daughter Ethel were held Friday afternoon. Friday 27 December 1929 Quaker City Home Towner.
 
Pinter, Robert N.
    Robert N. Pinter, 62, died Sunday Feb. 8, 2004.
     An Akron native, Mr. Pinter worked as a supervisor at SBC (Ohio Bell).  He was an Army veteran, and was a member of the Ohio Bell Pioneers.
     Preceded in ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Robert N. Pinter, 62, died Sunday Feb. 8, 2004.
An Akron native, Mr. Pinter worked as a supervisor at SBC (Ohio Bell). He was an Army veteran, and was a member of the Ohio Bell Pioneers.
Preceded in >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 death by his sister, Barbara Ebel, he is survived by his wife, Carol; daughter, Lisa Pinter; son, Robert Pinter; mother Dorothy Taylor; brother; John (Mary) Pinter; sister-in-law, Pat (Gene) Christoff; several nieces and nephews.

Pittman, Mildred Irene, nee Henthorn
Source--Monroe County Beacon    Woodsfield, Ohio
======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Woodsfield, Ohio >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711
Published---1999
     Mildred ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Mildred >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Irene Pittman, 79, 49780 Headley Ridge Road, Barnesville, died Sunday, April 4, 1999, in Wheeling Hospital. She was born June 24, 1919, in Adams Township, Monroe County, a daughter of the late Everett Charles and Susie Stewart Henthorn.
     She was a member of the Zion Church of Christ, Beallsville.
     In addition ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> She was a member of the Zion Church of Christ, Beallsville.
In addition >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 to her parents, she was preceded in death by her husband, Roy Ellsworth Pittman; a grandson, Roy J. "RJ" Ady; two brothers, Lawrence Cecil and Everett Okey Henthorn.
     Surviving are nine sons, Everett of Bowling Green, Ky., Roy Jr. of Oakland, Ky, Guy and Duane, both of Beallsville, James of Woodsfield, Roger and Bill, both of Sardis, Carl of Burbank, Ohio, Sam of Moundsville;  five daughters, Hazel Blackstone of ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Surviving are nine sons, Everett of Bowling Green, Ky., Roy Jr. of Oakland, Ky, Guy and Duane, both of Beallsville, James of Woodsfield, Roger and Bill, both of Sardis, Carl of Burbank, Ohio, Sam of Moundsville; five daughters, Hazel Blackstone of >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Wadsworth, Hilda Blackstone of Lewisville, Helen Palmer, Corilda Knowlton and Barb Ady, all of Beallsville; two brothers, Charles Henthorn of Akron and Clarence of Wadsworth; a sister, Wanda Blackstone of Lewisville; 45 grandchildren; 35 great-grandchildren.
     Services ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Services >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 will be held today, April 7,at 1 p.m. at the Harper Funeral Home, 52728 Ohio Ave., Beallseville, with Wayne Clark officiating. Burial follows in East Sunsbury Cemetery, Beallsville.

MARRIAGE of Timothy W. Stimpert and Angie Pfalzgraf
Source:The Monroe County Beacon, Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs., February18, 1982
  On January 23, 1982, Angie Pfalzgraf became the bride of Timothy W. Stimpert at the home of the brides grandmother, Mrs. D. L. Harkins of Caldwell, Ohio.
  The bride is the ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> On January 23, 1982, Angie Pfalzgraf became the bride of Timothy W. Stimpert at the home of the bride s grandmother, Mrs. D. L. Harkins of Caldwell, Ohio.
The bride is the >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 daughter of Jack and Shirley Pfalzgraf of Lewisville, Ohio. The bridegroom is the son of Robert and Shirley Stimpert, also of Lewisville.
  Sheldon Blair ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Sheldon Blair >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 of Marietta performed the double-ring ceremony. Stacey Lucas, sister of the bride, was matron of honor. Darrell Stimpert, brother of the groom, was best man.
  The bride wore ivory lace floor-length gown with an ivory veil styled by the matron of honor. The matron of honor wore a peach colored floor-length gown accented with White lace. Both carried bouquets of peach Roses, White daisy mums, White spider mums, and babys breath.
  Immediately following the ceremony, a reception was held.
  The bride is a ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> The bride wore ivory lace floor-length gown with an ivory veil styled by the matron of honor. The matron of honor wore a peach colored floor-length gown accented with White lace. Both carried bouquets of peach Roses, White daisy mums, White spider mums, and baby s breath.
Immediately following the ceremony, a reception was held.
The bride is a >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 senior at Skyvue High School. The groom is a 1981 graduate of Skyvue High School, Graysville, Ohio, and Swiss Hills Vocational School,
Woodsfield, Ohio. After a short wedding trip to Marietta, the couple now resides at Route 2, Lewisville, Ohio.

======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711
Postlethwait, Michael Allen
Source--Wetzel County Message Board      West Virginia
======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> West Virginia >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711
Published--January 15, 2001
 
======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711
Postlethwait, Michael Allen , 26, of New Martinsville, died Monday, January 15, 2001, at his home.
He was a son of Susie I. Postlethwait Coen of New Martinsville, and the late Allen Dale Weekley who preceded him in death in November 2000.
Also surviving are one daughter, Tosha Lee Postlethwait, a friend, Tammy Phillips, both of Powhatan Point, Ohio; three brothers, Donald Postlethwait, Proctor, Brandon Leek and Jeremy Leek, both of New Martinsville; three sisters, Tracy Postlethwait, Paden City, Florence Leek, New Martinsville, and Genine Kellar, Reader; his maternal grandmother, Alice Postlethwait, Paden City; his paternal grandparents, Henry Weekley, New Jersey, and Florence Weekley, New Martinsville.
He was also preceded in death by his maternal grandfather, Pete Postlethwait.
Mr. Postlethwait was a Protestant by faith.
Arrangements by Palmer Funeral Home, Pine Grove, West Virginia.

>>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711
 
Postlewait, Paul

Clarington
 
Postlethwait, Samuel C.
Source--Wetzel Message Board    West Virginia
======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> West Virginia >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711
Published--May 1994
 
======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711
POSTLETHWAIT, Samuel C., 81 of New Martinsville, died Wednesday, May 4, 1994, in Wetzel County Hospital, New Martinsville. He was born February 1, 1913 in Wetzel County. He was a retired janitor at Ormet Corporation., Hannibal, Ohio and a member of the Church of God, New Martinsville. He was preceded in death by two sons, Ernest Lee and Bobby; his parents, Sam and Bertha Carroll Postlethwait. Surviving are his wife, Dorothy Bennett Postlethwait; four sons, Sam of Warren, Ohio, Curtis and Edward, both of New Martinsville and Fred of Paden City; three adopted sons, David, James and Joey, all of New Martinsville; a brother Joseph of Shinnston; 10 grandchildren; six great-grandchildren. Friends were received at Iams Funeral Home, New Martinsville where services were held with Doctor Larry McCallister officiating. Interment in Straight Cemetery, Reader.

Potts, Merle F.
July 12th, 2004
 
Potts, Merle F., age 73 of State Route 7, Duffy, Ohio died Monday, July 12, 2004 at home.
He was born September 29, 1930 in Duffy, Ohio the son of the late Walter Franklin and Amanda Elizabeth Longwell Potts.
He was a Korean Conflict Army Veteran, a retired construction laborer from Local #1149, a member of 1st Church of God, Duffy, VFW Post 9930, Duffy, Moose Lodge #2247, Woodsfield, Ohio, American Legion Post 28, <<<<<<< HEAD New Martinsville, F.O.E, Paden City, Elks Lodge 333, Sistersville.
In addition to his parents, he was preceded in death by four brothers, Claude Potts, Martin Oakie Potts, Webster Potts, and Walter Junie Potts, five sisters, Mary Francis Potts, Margaret Maggie Yeager, Luella Sis Hudson, Lavina Gehring and Martha Vercamen.
======= New Martinsville, F.O.E, Paden City, Elk s Lodge 333, Sistersville.
In addition to his parents, he was preceded in death by four brothers, Claude Potts, Martin Oakie Potts, Webster Potts, and Walter Junie Potts, five sisters, Mary Francis Potts, Margaret Maggie Yeager, Luella Sis Hudson, Lavina Gehring and Martha Vercamen.
>>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711
Survivors include his wife, Marjorie M. SchooNovemberer Potts, a son, Francis (Marla) Potts of Hannibal, two daughters, Jeannie (Tony) Pletcher of Sardis and Pam (Ron) Bennett of Hannibal, a brother, Jones (Ann) Potts of Channahon, Illinois and eight grandchildren, Phillip (Anissa) Pletcher and Nathan and Kayla Pletcher, James Ryan, Carrie and Jordan Potts and Amanda and Allison Bennett.
Family will receive friends on Thursday from 2-4 and 7-9pm at Grisell Funeral Home, 37234 Mound St., Sardis where funeral services will be held on Friday at 11am with Rev. Cathy Harman and Rev. Frank Conley officiating. Interment in Harter Cemetery, Hannibal where American Legion Post 760 will conduct Military graveside services.
 
Source--Grisell Funeral Homes     On-Line-Obituaries

 Charles POULTON
               Charles POULTON, aged about 44 ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Charles POULTON
Charles POULTON, aged about 44 >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 years, died Wednesday morning, March 29, 1916, after a shot illness. Mr. Poulton had been engaged in the barbering business in Woodsfield for many years. He leaves a wife and four children, his mother and several sisters. Deceased was a son of Oswald POULTON who died some years ago. He was a member of the Catholic Church.

Poulton, Joshua A.

Poulton, Louisa E.
Died: October 1931
 
Powell, Bertha Olive
 Bertha Olive Powell was born at Somerton, Ohio, January 30, 1894 and departed this life November 28, 1928.  Being at the time of her death thirty-four years, nine months and twenty-nine days.  She married Henry P. Leach July 4, 1922 and two sons were born, both living.  She became a member of the Church of Christ at the age of fifteen years and has lived a Christian life ever since.  She leaves to mourn her loss her husband and two little sons;  also her father and mother, Mr. and Mrs. Jacob Powell,  three brothers and one sister and a host of loving relatives and friends.
  Funeral was ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Bertha Olive Powell was born at Somerton, Ohio, January 30, 1894 and departed this life November 28, 1928. Being at the time of her death thirty-four years, nine months and twenty-nine days. She married Henry P. Leach July 4, 1922 and two sons were born, both living. She became a member of the Church of Christ at the age of fifteen years and has lived a Christian life ever since. She leaves to mourn her loss her husband and two little sons; also her father and mother, Mr. and Mrs. Jacob Powell, three brothers and one sister and a host of loving relatives and friends.
Funeral was >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 conducted by Elder Parsons of Malta, Ohio and burial was in the Southern Cemetery.
  Relatives who attended the funeral from a distance were;  Mr. and Mrs. T. M. Brown,  Mrs. Ola McElroy, Mr. Ernest McElroy of Baden, Pa;  Mr. and Mrs Alex Leach,  Mr. and Mrs. Charles Leach,  Mr. Clarence Leach, Mrs. Pleas Leach,  Mr. and Mrs. Woodruff of Canton;  Mr. W. T. Botkin,  Mrs. Bert Tolger, Cambridge;  Mr. Fred Botkin, Centerville,  Mr. and Mrs. Glenn Zogg,  Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Scott;  Mrs. Hershel Harper,  Mrs. Katherine Brown, Woodsfield,  Mrs. Herbert Tacker, Youngstown,  Mrs. Walter Buckey, Malaga.  Thursday 6 Dec. 1928 Barnesville Whetstone.

Powell, Dessie R.
April 6, 1913Beallsville, Ohio
May 13, 2003
 
Powell, George
 George Powell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Homer Powell passed away at the family home south of Batesville Tuesday morning following an illness of tuberculosis.  He had been in poor health for several months and following the death of his only brother Earl, last February to whom he was very closely attached, life seemed to have little meaning for him.  His condition however,  had been critical only a few days.  George Powell was born on the farm where he died,  January 8, 1902 and lived there his lifetime where he was well known and liked by a host of friends.  Besides his parents he is survived by two sisters, Mrs. Cleve Carpenter of near Calais and Mrs. Arch Leach of near Salesville.  Short funeral services were held at the home this (Thursday) morning at 10 o'clock conducted by Rev. Hinman, pastor of the Batesville M. E. Church,  additional services being held shortly after at the Baptist Church south of Batesville.  Interment was made in the church cemetery.  Thursday 30 November. ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> George Powell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Homer Powell passed away at the family home south of Batesville Tuesday morning following an illness of tuberculosis. He had been in poor health for several months and following the death of his only brother Earl, last February to whom he was very closely attached, life seemed to have little meaning for him. His condition however, had been critical only a few days. George Powell was born on the farm where he died, January 8, 1902 and lived there his lifetime where he was well known and liked by a host of friends. Besides his parents he is survived by two sisters, Mrs. Cleve Carpenter of near Calais and Mrs. Arch Leach of near Salesville. Short funeral services were held at the home this (Thursday) morning at 10 o'clock conducted by Rev. Hinman, pastor of the Batesville M. E. Church, additional services being held shortly after at the Baptist Church south of Batesville. Interment was made in the church cemetery. Thursday 30 November. >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 1930 Quaker City Home Towner.

  Mr. Powell ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Funeral services for Gillispie (Glass) Powell, 91, Batesville, were held at 1:30 P.M. Wednesday at the Eberle Funeral Home, Quaker City. Rev. Allan Teter officiating and burial was in Batesville Cemetery.
Mr. Powell >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 died at 7:33 P.M. Monday, November. 24, at Barnesville Hospital where he had been a patient since Oct. 21, having undergone surgery.
  He was born Sept. 8, 1878 at Calais,  the son of William and Mary Carpenter Powell.
  Mr. Powell leaves one son, Harold of Batesville;  one sister, Kate Brownfield, Barnesville;  four grandchildren;  seven great-grandchildren and several nieces and nephews.  His wife, Bertha, died in October, 1965, and two sons, three sisters and four brothers are deceased.  Friday 28 November. 1969 Quaker City Home ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> He was born Sept. 8, 1878 at Calais, the son of William and Mary Carpenter Powell.
